author: ituckey
title: Jurgen Klopp finally admits Liverpool’s calamity keepers Simon Mignolet and Lorius Karius are ‘causing problems’ for Reds
text:
FOR once, Jurgen Klopp did not turn a blind to eye to the blindingly obvious. 
The Liverpool boss has previously gone to great lengths to defend his two calamity keepers. PA:Press Association 5 Jurgen Klopp has publicly confessed Liverpool have issues with their No 1 spot 
But after another humiliation at Hull, Klopp finally confessed the dire displays of Simon Mignolet and Loris Karius are “causing problems.” 
The German now knows he cannot keep covering for their cock-ups. 
Mignolet was embarrassed when David Luiz caught him napping with his free-kick for Chelsea at Anfield on Tuesday. 
And on Saturday, under pressure from Hull’s Abel Hernandez, he pathetically palmed down Harry Maguire’s header for Alfred N’Diaye to tap in. 
Of course, the Belgian’s blunders are nothing new. 
You could compile a whole DVD of goalkeeping gaffes just from Mignolet ’s 3½ years at Liverpool . Yet Klopp’s only alternative is to resort back to Karius . 
And the German’s own horror highlights reel comes with an 18 certificate. 
Still, Klopp has in the past been nothing but supportive of his stoppers. PA:Press Association Simon Mignolet blunders again, enabling Alfred N’Diaye to poach the first Hull goal Liverpool keeper Simon Mignolet drops a corner which leads to a Hull goal 
He memorably attacked Gary and Phil Neville after the pundits criticised Karius in December. 
But the Anfield boss is seemingly no longer prepared to tell the world and his wife that they have got it wrong about his men between the sticks. 
Asked about Mignolet ’s mistake at Hull, Klopp said: “That’s another thing where we have to show a reaction. That’s causing problems. That’s how it is. 
“For sure, he was not alone around the goal. But he nearly had the ball in his hands. 
“We cannot ignore this is true and we will not — we do not lie to ourselves. Putting ourselves under pressure is a hobby of ours. Now we have to show a reaction, but I cannot show it here now.” 
This was not the same clippity Klopp who bounced into England 16 months ago with his endless energy and loveable laugh. 
Even after a defeat, the German usually comes out fighting in his post-match press duties. Reuters German Loris Karius has struggled to impress during his first season at Anfield Hull 2-0 Liverpool : Bottom-of-the-table Tigers stun drab Reds as Jurgen Klopp’s horror 2017 continues 
But on Saturday night, as he propped himself against the wall in a tight corridor of the KCOM Stadium, Klopp was like a boxer on the ropes. Gloves up, just taking the punches. 
He was asked why it is that Liverpool have not lost once against any team in the top ten, but have now been beaten four times by sides in the bottom half. 
Klopp was questioned if, in hindsight, he regrets not making any signings in last month’s transfer window when it was clear they needed fresh faces. 
And he was quizzed on just how he was going to turn things around given his lack of strength in depth. 
But Klopp had no answers, only insisting that his search for solutions would start right away. Getty Images 5 Oumar Niasse grabs the late Hull clincher on Saturday after visiting keeper Mignolet had been left unprotected by poor defending 
He said: “I think what is very important is to never blame anybody else for your own mistakes. 
“I cannot say, ‘Yes it would have been fantastic if the club could have given me new players’. We had opportunities for doing something but we didn’t find the right players. 
“It’s not because we were blind, it’s because the players were not available. We tried different things — it was not a money issue, there were different reasons.” 
Klopp continued: “But I take everything. If you say now, ‘Not enough players, not good enough players’. I have to take it.

“I respect all your questions. You have been pretty polite and nice when you could have been much more aggressive, and even that I would have accepted. 
“I don’t think I’m perfect. I feel 100 per cent responsible for defeats, much more than I feel for wins. It has been like this my whole life. 
“That doesn’t mean it’s for me to feel sorry for myself, to have self-pity, I’m not like this. When I get up on Sunday I will only be solution orientated. 
“And there are solutions, 100 per cent. But I cannot do it here now, that’s the problem.” 
The Reds might have enjoyed 72 per cent of possession and had 22 shots and 15 corners. But sometimes the stats do lie because against Marco Silva’s much- improved side deserved the three points. PA:Press Association Former Germany U-21 keeper Karius will be hoping to justify the £4.7m summer fee paid to Mainz 05 after his shaky start to life in the Premier League 
Liverpool never really recovered after debutant N’Diaye capitalised on Mignolet ’s mess in the 44th minute. 
And Oumar Niasse added a second from Andrea Ranocchia’s long ball six minutes from time, slotting through minging Mignolet ’s legs. 
Klopp added: “Many teams have already made mistakes and changed things. For this you have to do the right things and I’m quite confident we can do the right things. 
“We will see what happens in the week and how players react. 
“We don’t look for excuses, it’s not that we are trying to blame somebody. 
“We are responsible, the squad, myself especially. 
“We have to work on a solution and we will.” 
Good luck with that, Jurgen. You’re going to need it.
